name.text: 6.1.1.4 when x is any real number

questiontext.text:
Defining \(a^x\) when \(x\) is any real number

So far we have given the meaning of \(a^p\) where \(p\) is an integer or a rational number, that is, one which can be written as a quotient of integers. So, if \(p\) is rational, then \[\qquad p=\dfrac{m}{n}, \qquad \text{ where } m,n \text{ are integers}.   \]

Now consider \(x\) as a real number which cannot be written as a rational number. Two common examples of these irrational numbers are \(\sqrt{2}\) and \(\pi\). What we shall do is approximate \(x\) by a rational number by working to a fixed number of decimal places. For example if \[\qquad x=3.14159265\dots,  \] then, if we are working to 3 d.p., we would write \[\qquad x\approx 3.142,  \] and this number can certainly be expressed as a rational number: \[\qquad x\approx 3.142=\dfrac{3142}{1000},  \] so in this case \[\qquad a^x=a^{3.14159\dots}\approx a^{3.142}=a^{\dfrac{3142}{1000}}. \] and the final term: \( a^{\dfrac{3142}{1000}} \) can be determined in the usual way by  calculator. Henceforth, we shall therefore assume that the expression \(a^x\) is defined for all positive values of \(a\) and for  all real values of \(x\).

This approach will allow us, with some care, to approximate \(a^x\) for any real numbers.
